The great selection chapter on the path of the king of the great empty dust ocean treasury, chapter 35. Having explained the great selection chapter on the ocean of liberation that is vast and inexhaustible, we will now explain the great selection chapter on the path of the king of the great empty dust ocean treasury.
What are its characteristics?
A verse says:
In the path of the king of the ocean, there are a hundred kinds of mastery,
For this reason, the name of the king of the ocean is established.
The treatise says:
What meaning does this verse clarify now?
It is in order to reveal that there is no separate dharma in the treasury of the king of the ocean, only mastery.
How many kinds of mastery are there?
It means there are a hundred kinds.
What are the hundred?

First, mastery over time, with thirty-two dharmas, turning at the same time and turning at different times, turning within the time of turning and not turning, not turning within the time of turning, turning at a distant time and turning at a near time, and so forth, up to immeasurable.
Second, mastery over place, turning in the same place and different places, and so forth, up to immeasurable.
Third, mastery over objects, for the same and different uses, and so forth, up to immeasurable.
Fourth, mastery over pervasiveness, penetrating everywhere and so forth, up to immeasurable.
Fifth, mastery over size, extremely heavy, extremely subtle, and so forth, up to immeasurable.
Sixth, mastery over existence and non-existence, manifesting and concealing, and so forth, up to immeasurable.
Seventh, mastery over stillness and movement, both concentrated and scattered, and so forth, up to immeasurable.
Eighth, mastery over profundity, inconceivable matters, and so forth, up to immeasurable.

Ninth, non-sovereign sovereignty, because of immeasurable things such as going against and so forth.ğŸ”½Tenth, unobstructed sovereignty, because of immeasurable things such as going against and following and so forth.
Up to the hundredth sovereignty, sovereignty over inexhaustible sovereignty and so forth are all sovereign, because of immeasurable things.

As the thirty-two dharmas explained above, such sovereignty is complete and perfect without deficiency, and because of this meaning, the name of the ocean king is established, which should be carefully considered.
As a verse says: On the path of the ocean king, there are a hundred sovereignties, and for this reason, the name of the ocean king is established.
In the Flower of Awakening Sutra, it is said:

In the first vast division of the ocean gate, if explained in detail, there are as many sovereignties as there are dust motes in a world system in the ten directions, and if explained in brief, there are a hundred sovereignties.
And so on, it is explained in detail.

Having explained the chapter on the path of the great empty dust ocean treasury king, next is the explanation of the chapter on the great inconceivable, multilayered, incalculable, and supremely profound king of great selection and analysis.
What are its characteristics?
A verse says:
Within the supremely profound king, there are the number of dust motes in the ten directions,
The number of dust motes in the empty space of the ten directions, and thirty-three dharma oceans.
The treatise says:
What meaning does this verse clarify?

It is in order to manifest and demonstrate that within the ocean of the supremely profound, there are the number of dust motes in the ten directions of worlds, the number of dust motes in the ten directions of worlds, and thirty-three dharma oceans, the number of dust motes in the ten directions of worlds, the number of dust motes in the empty space of the ten directions, and thirty-three dharma oceans.

As a verse says: In the root king of the Avatamsaka Sutra, there are as many as the dust particles in the ten directions, and as many as the dust particles in the ten directions of empty space, thirty-three Dharma oceans.
In the Sutra of the Root King, it is said:
At that time, the World-Honored One told the great assembly:
'I, with the wisdom of the three insights, have thoroughly penetrated all dharmas, without obstruction or deficiency.

Yet there is one ocean that is inconceivable, beyond conception, and cannot be fully understood, namely, the ocean of the inexhaustible treasury of the perfect freedom and sovereignty of the inherent virtues of the nature of the root king of empty dust.'
And so on, it is explained in detail.
